IBM Support requested more information about the high uninitialized LUNs/hosts and any observed hardware issues. They also requested information on which LSS/host were consuming high load during the specified time stamps. IBM Support also requested spectrum control reports for the time frame 07-10-2024 10:00 - 17:00 hrs from all the 3 storage systems. IBM Support analyzed the reports and provided a table with the replication bandwidth for each system during the specified time stamps. The maximum combined send replication bandwidth for the two systems did not exceed 4Gbps, and the maximum send replication bandwidth for the third system did not exceed 2.5Gbps. IBM Support also noted SAN congestion on the metro mirror ports in all three DS8K systems, which could impact the write latency of host applications. They recommended engaging with the SAN Support team to analyze the buffer starvation issue on the metro mirror ports and engaging with link vendors to optimize the link latencies. ICICI Bank later requested information on the sessions running during the specified time frame, but IBM Support noted that session related information is not available in spectrum control performance package. However, there is SAN congestion on the metro mirror ports in all the 3 DS8K systems, which can have an impact on the write latency of the host applications. Recommendations to resolve the issue include engaging with the SAN Support team to analyze the buffer starvation issue on the metro mirror ports and engaging with link vendors to optimize the link latencies to be as close to each other as possible. No actions are recommended on the DS8K systems. Solution Attempts *Generated by watsonx*: The hardware analysis shows that all 3 DS8K storage systems are operating in optimal status during the specified problem window and there are no hardware issues that can lead to a performance problem. The support team has requested more information, including clarification of what is meant by high uninitialized LUNs/hosts, a list of affected lss/volume IDs/volume group/cluster/host on each DS8K system, and details about the impact to the application due to the reported performance problem. They have also asked for observations from the database and OS perspectives.

Body: Customer Sentiment negative Description Summary The customer is unable to add a non-self-signed certificate to a new secure SMTP server with TLS, as the certificate is not accepted by DCM due to a missing request. The customer has attempted many fixes, including resetting DCM, but the issue remains unresolved. The customer is seeking assistance in creating a valid certificate and having it accepted by DCM, as well as any other considerations for setting up a new SMTP server. Feed Summary Customer was unable to add a non-self-signed certificate to their SMTP server and needed help creating a valid certificate and having it accepted by DCM. The customer was trying to import a certificate to configure SSL/TLS between IBM i and a remote mail router, but encountered an error message that "no request has been created for this certificate". The customer had already tried numerous attempts to clear the DCM and restart from scratch. The support team provided instructions for the customer to clear the DCM and configure SMTP, and the customer followed these instructions. However, the customer was still unable to send mail after completing these steps. The support team requested that the customer provide a trace of the SMTP configuration and the job log, as well as the DCM applications and store. The customer provided these files and the support team was able to determine that the issue was due to a problem with TLS (trusted CA) and that the certificate was not signed by a trusted certificate authority. The support team identified that the CA "GTS Root R1" was missing and needed to be imported and trusted in the DCM for the Application ID: QIBM\_QTMS\_SMTP\_CLIENT. The customer was able to locate the CA with the serial number provided by the support team, but was unable to find the CA with the serial number "0203e5936f31b01349886ba217". The support team was able to confirm that the imported CA was correct and that the issue was due to the IP address of the SMTP server not being the same as the customer's. The support team provided instructions for the customer to run a PING and openssl command to retrieve the IP address of the SMTP server and the certificate chain. The customer provided the spool file and the support team was able to determine that the CA chain was correct and that the issue was due to the SMTP process taking the host name specified for forwarding mailhub server and getting the MX record IP address for it, which was resulting in an invalid.invalid CA and a 6000 error. To resolve the issue, the support team changed the SMTP client APP ID to use only TLSV1.2 and the customer was able to send mail successfully. The customer agreed to close the case. Nothing unusual and totally normal processing. I think I see from where the confusion is coming on and I apologize for not being clear enough with my updates. At the time I was doing the analysis of the syslog, I thought the IXC567I message at 22:10:31.75 was the last message in the log containing information about Logger component in it(XCF structure used by CF based log stream). The SETLOGRC LOGSTREAM command I had in mind was issued at 22:38:43.32 and it was mentioned just to indicate start of Logger activity. I think by the time I've put the update, it was clear that the system had experienced I/O issues with devices 7501 where primary LOGR CDS resides and 7702 where the alternate LOGR CDS resides. So the first message that indicates that the system has troubles performing I/O operations to the device with LOGR CDS is: So the system issues that set of messages indicating IO issues at: 22:40:13.86, 22:40:54.86, 22:41:35.88, 22:42:17.89, 22:42:58.90, 22:43:41.92, 22:44:22.93, 22:45:04.94, 22:45:46.96, 22:46:29.97, 22:47:11.97, 22:47:53.99, 22:49:34.03, 22:50:15.37(SYS4) 22:50:16.03, 22:50:56.38(SYS4), 22:50:57.05, 22:51:37.39(SYS4), 22:51:39.07, 22:52:19.40(SYS4), 22:52:20.07, 22:53:01.08, 22:53:02.41(SYS4), 22:53:42.10, 22:53:44.43(SYS4), 22:57:45.18, 22:58:27.18, 22:59:09.19, 22:59:50.21, 22:59:52.53(SYS4)! Explanation ----------- AIX paging mechanism works so that once written to paging space, pages are not removed from paging space until one of the following happens: (1) the process associated with those pages terminates (in case of shared memory, ALL associated processes) (2) disclaim() system call is issued by that process (which applications usually don't do) (3) swapoff/swapon is executed (this requires more than one paging space configured) For long running processes (Oracle db processes are a typical example), even low levels of system paging will result in significant growth in paging space usage over time. As per above even if the system is only experiencing paging during occasional workload peaks (as already pointed out above, this might only happen on very rare occasions), this will cause constant increase in allocated paging space. Even though not used, paging space will stay allocated till owning processes exit or machine is rebooted or it is cleared by swapoff/swapon. Kernel also needs some small amount of paging space to create new processes (forking) so when it starts running out of paging space it will start killing processes to free some paging space. In case paging space is just allocated by long running processes, but not actually used, it is still not available and the system will sooner or later hang, or some cluster monitoring process will crash it before that (eviction).
